Benzene is not a combination of two versions of cyclohexatriene.  That would mean that all three pi orbitals are at the same energy level (and the three empty anti-bonding orbitals would also be at the same energy level).  It has one strongly bonding molecular orbital that results from combining all six 2p orbitals in the same direction, two bonding MOs from combining four in the same direction and two in the opposite direction, and three anti-bonding orbitals (which are empty in the ground state).  http://www.chemtube3d.com/BenzeneMOs.html
The schematic drawings of hybrid orbitals seem to show a node at the nucleus.  The nucleus is really inside the large lobe, right?

Clearest Lyrics Tetrahedral geometry the bonds are orientated @ 109.5 degrees apart because this maximizes the distance between each region of electron density. Remember it is a 3D structure, not flat.
why?
By looking at the blackboard it seems to me that the CO molecule has the pi x and y orbitals with 2 electrons each, they become just 1 electron for each pi orbital for the cation CO(2+)

well, phosphorus has 5 valence electrons and hydrogen has 1 each so you get a total of 8 valence electrons. Since you need 14 to get full shells, cause phosphorus needs 8 to be full and Hydrogen needs 2, you subtract the original number of electrons, which is 8, from the number that you need, which is 14, to see how many electrons you need for the bonding, which is 6.

The phosphorous wants 8 electrons to gain a full octet (i.e. full valence shell) and the hydrogens want 2 electrons to gain a full valence shell. 8 electron for phosphorous and 3x2=6 electrons for all the hydrogens = 14 electrons. This is the amount of electrons needed for all atoms to have full valence shells. We have 8 valence electrons for all atoms. The 14-8=6 is giving us the number of bonding electrons.

David Méry saral123456789  Well, thank you for your answers. They really helped. What my question really was, is that WHY do all that to find the number of bonding electrons ? In PH3, for example Hydrogen can only make single bonds and hence it is evident that there will be 3 phosphorous - hydrogen bonds and thus 2 x 3 = 6 bonding electrons. I really don't understand the purpose of doing all that calculation for this result. More over I guess you both used octet and duplet rules to find out the number of bonding electrons. Actually octet rule doesn't hold in all cases --> what I mean by that is 'there are many compounds which violate octet rule' for example SF6, XeF6, ... and the list goes on. Thus, I think using something that isn't ALWAYS true is not very very good. This method would fail in cases like XeF6. The only way in which you can find the number of bonding electrons is this ;- F makes single bonds thus 6 F atoms would make 6 bonds and thus there would be 12 bonding electrons. Anyway, thanks for your replies. :)

Aritra Das These are freshmen courses which finish in first 4-8 months of the American college. They teach advance subjects from second year. I see indians talking about how their education is far ahead of American. I totally disagree with that. They teach advance topic like quantum mechanics after these introductory courses. I took 11-12 class from the Indian board. Whole modern chemistry is based on wave equation but not a single time was taught about the wave equation.  Don't lie that you knew Schrodinger's equation before watching MIT's video. They teach these things in IIT(bachelors) in India. For my case, Indian Teacher, with 40 years, experiences were able to perplexed everybody. Even books and syllabus are totally different in India.   AS I said American high school also teach this but some opt out. So, they have to re-teach everybody again from the beginning.
